evidence: the goal is to capture not just how different two images are, but how similar they are
The similarity between X and Y should be the same as the similarity between Y and X
The similarity value should always be between zero and one
The similarity should only reach the maximum value of one if the two images are exactly the same
SSIM is designed to satisfy all of these postulates
The goal is to capture not just how different two images are, but how similar they are.
The similarity between X and Y should be the same as the similarity between Y and X.
The similarity value should always be between zero and one.
The similarity should only reach the maximum value of one if the two images are exactly the same, pixel for pixel.
When we construct a similarity measure, the goal is to capture not just how different two images are, but how similar they are.
First, symmetry. The similarity between X and Y should be the same as the similarity between Y and X.
Second, boundedness. The similarity value should always be between zero and one.
Third, a unique maximum. The similarity should only reach the maximum value of one if the two images are exactly the same, pixel for pixel.

The similarity value should always be between zero and one.
The similarity should only reach the maximum value of one if the two images are exactly the same, pixel for pixel.
